THE THIRD NAPOLEON. I Poet! graced by royal feeling With Britannia's laurel crown, Whose fair roundâthe light revealing Both of late and old renownâ Yet shall shine with added splendour, Ere thy brows the gift surrenderâ II Poet! deal no more in fiction; Trick no hero of the brain; Measured verse, and gorgeous diction, Spent on Myths, are spent in vain. Look around. Behold the Real Far transcend thy loved Ideal. III Take a Boy, by birth connected With Imperial pomp and state, And describe him thence dejected By a thunderbolt of fate, Whichâinto his young House drivenâ Strews it to each point of heaven! The fall of Napoleon I. IV Sing the youthful Outcast wandering Over lands that hold but foes; Yet where'er he wanders, pondering To his ills a glorious close; One sad Spirit hovering o'er him, And a hero's path before him! V Paint that path beset with perilâ More attractive, so beset! Paint the ground it leads through, sterileâ That, be sure, will blossom yet! Paint it darkâthe night is breaking, And the dawn shall see a waking! VI Sing him watching the first ray break Through yon clouds so thick and grimâ Ah! that gleam is not the daybreak Which is yet to shine on him! That is but a meteor risen, And it lures him to aâprison! Louis Napoleon's capture and imprisonment under Louis Philippe. VII Sing him to a prison hurried, In the land he hoped to ruleâ All his schemes of grandeur buried With the Madman or the Fool. So the world, with bent distressful, Still thinks of the Unsuccessful! VIII Sing him to a prison taken, And when Fear his life would claim, Lo! his Captorâawed and shaken By the spell-word of his Nameâ Spares it,âthe damnation dreading Which would follow his blood-shedding! IX Paint him hoping stillâthough fettered; Still confidingâthough immured; Heart, in every impulse, bettered; Mind, in every power, matured. Length of durance will but find him Fitter for the part assigned him. X Paint his prison guarded slackly, And his fetters from him hurledâ When a smoke-cloud rises blackly, And an Earthquake shakes the world. The French Revolution of 1848. How he watches that appearance! What beholds he at the clearance? XI One proud Throneâhis Captor'sâshattered, Which seemed built for stable sway; One proud King, but last night flattered, Flying in disguise to-day; And a hundred eager Claimants For his Officeâand its payments! XII Sing him Claimant too, as one who, Born a Prince, the land would serve; And, among his rivals, none who Touch, like him, the public nerve! How hath he each heart enraptured? By the word which saved himâcaptured! XIII That same wordâthe Name bequeathed him By a Hero idolisedâ That Name hath as Victor wreathed him O'er a hundred Chiefsâdespised! Millions call him forth to govern, And the Outcast standsâa Sovereign! XIV Vain have been proscriptionâexile; Vain the brand on name and race; Monarch firm, and Monarch flexile, Charles X. and Louis Philippe. Each resigns the destined place; Heâthe Banned and Banishedâfills it: An exulting Nation wills it! XV Sing him hampered yet by factions, All of whom have triedâto fail; Yet who form disgraceful pactions To obstruct, annoy, assail; Men whoâproud, pretentious, hollowâ Can not lead, and will not follow! XVI Oneânot allâmust be commander; Who shall loose the knotted cord? Heâanother Alexanderâ Boldly cuts it with his sword! Turn not from some blood, abhorrentâ That slight stream hath saved a torrent! Severity, in revolutionary tumults, is often true mercy. A single word spoken by Louis Philippe to his general, might have saved his throne, and prevented the butchery which took place in the streets of Paris only three months afterwards; compared with which the blood-shed of the coup d'Ã©tat was as nothing. XVII Sing him Power Imperial wielding, Not as one to empire born; But the toiling millions shielding, Whom a king by birth might scorn. Pamper, kings! the favoured classesâ He is Monarch of the Masses! XVIII Paint him now as busied only For their weal in councils grave: But his hallsâshall they be lonely? Shall the fair not bless the brave? âNone but the brave deserves the fair.â âDryden. Lo! a more than Poet's Vision Turns his bowers to bowers Elysian! The Emperor's marriage with one of the most beautiful women in Europe. XIX Paint him generous, not forgetting How a captive he had lain; And a glorious Chieftain setting Abd-el-Kader, the hero of Lord Maidstone's fine poem. Free from an unworthy chain. Bound by craven fears he finds himâ Fearless Clemency unbinds him! XX Sing himâheir to war and gloryâ Slighting glory gained by war; Coveting, for laurels gory, Bloodless palm-wreathsâfairer far; Marshallingâa moral Movement; Heading armiesâof Improvement! XXI Objects noble! But his subjects, Madly fond of fame in arms, Will they find those noble objects Clothed, to them, with equal charms? Can he, while such dreams disturb them, Curbâand yet not seem to curbâthem? XXII Aye!âBefore that powerful spirit, And that firm, determined will, Each war-bias they inherit, Shrinks, discouragedâand is still. Valour, till the time's expedient, Sheaths his half-drawn bladeâobedient! XXIII Sing him thus triumphantâwanting But one spell to fix his sway; And his wondrous Fortune granting That too, in her wondrous wayâ War which, waked in distant regions, Gratifies his martial legions; XXIV Warâto rescue from oppression Weak states, overborne by strong; Warâto check unjust aggression, Help the Right, and crush the Wrong; Warâto spill men's blood like water, Waged for Ends that hallow Slaughter! XXV Sing him in that War a Leader, Prompt, for those high Ends, to strike;â Then, concluding, bid thy reader Show, in tale or song, his Like! Proudly for thy Hero claim him, And The Third Napoleon name him!
